summary: This document is an email chain between U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York (USANYS) personnel and a PAE contractor regarding significant delays in processing and producing electronic discovery for the U.S. v. Epstein case. The correspondence expresses frustration over 1-2 month delays, concerns about missing a court-imposed deadline (November 9, 2020), and mentions the shipment of several productions (SDNYPROD008-014).

persons.name: Lead E-Discovery Analyst
persons.context: PAE contractor who sends an email detailing the status of electronic discovery productions being shipped to SDNY and the imaging of approximately 1.2 million records.

persons.name: Judge Nathan
persons.context: Mentioned as the judge before whom the SDNY team is concerned about missing a discovery deadline, potentially facing consequences.

connections.description: The analyst's company (PAE) is processing discovery for a case being overseen by Judge Nathan. Delays in the analyst's work create a risk of the legal team missing the judge's deadline.

events.title: Court Discovery Deadline
events.description: A court-imposed deadline for producing discovery in the U.S. v. Epstein case, which the SDNY team is concerned about missing due to processing delays.

events.title: Earliest Image Availability
events.description: The date by which images for approximately 1.2 million records being processed are estimated to become available in the Relativity workspace.

events.title: Shipment of Discovery Productions
events.description: A hard drive containing productions SDNYPROD008 through SDNYPROD014 is sent via FedEx to the SDNY.

locations: 7799 Leesburg Pike, Suite 300N Falls Church, Virginia 22043
keyFacts: The document reveals significant delays (1-2 months) in processing electronic discovery for the U.S. v. Epstein case, causing major operational hurdles for the prosecution team.
The prosecution team expresses serious concern about missing a court deadline (November 9, 2020) set by Judge Nathan and potentially facing consequences.
Approximately 1.2 million records were still being imaged as of October 30, 2020, highlighting the massive volume of material in the case.
Multiple specific productions (SDNYPROD008 through SDNYPROD014) were being shipped, indicating an ongoing, large-scale discovery process.
The correspondence involves a contractor from PAE, a company handling e-discovery, showing the external resources involved in the investigation.
